awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds work to compare the distribution and abundance of volatiles in the early solar system with those in protoplanetary disks around other stars, and test models of planetary formation.  The PI and her team will focus on measuring the abundance ratio of carbon monoxide (CO) to carbon dioxide (CO2) gases in a diverse set of small icy bodies, including comets and Kuiper Belt Objects (KBOs), orbiting the Sun at large distances.  CO and CO2 are both key volatiles that are among the primary drivers of comet activity and are important tracers for studying the chemical composition of the early solar system. The researchers will accomplish this with analysis of new observations and existing databases of comets and KBOs. The PI will train and mentor two postdoctoral researchers and work with computer science and electrical engineering students graduate students in a summer school program using astronomical data.

Specific objectives include conducting optical follow up for newly discovered and previously known active comets in order to estimate CO/CO2 gas fluxes, obtaining high resolution near-IR spectra and sub-mm observations on bright comets seen by the WISE telescope in order to detect CO, employing Finson-Probstein dust dynamical models, utilize data from the Pan STARRS1 survey telescope, and the team's existing photometry database to create simple sublimation models to understand the activity over a range of distances. They will also develop ways to visualize portions of the data set in a 3D mini-CAVE environment to enable new types of science exploration.

por.por_cntn:
Observations of the Solar System provide insight into the distribution and processing of dust and volatiles in the protosolar disk, into giant planet migration, and into dynamical mixing of the debris disk.  Comets are fossils from the early Solar System, containing unique information on the composition and evolution of the middle to outer protoplanetary disk.  The most abundant volatiles that take place in the process of star and planet formation other than hydrogen include carbon dioxide (CO2), carbon monoxide (CO) and water (H2O).  Direct observation to trace the process of planet formation and the distribution of volatiles in the habitable regions of planetary systems has been challenging because (1) we lacked the resolution necessary to trace processes in the inner disk and (2) because CO2 cannot be observed from the ground.  The Deep Impact and EPOXI comet missions have shown that CO2 may be more important in controlling comet activity than CO or water when close to the sun.  Moreover, the in-situ data have allowed us to test indirect techniques for observing CO2 from the ground, and for the first time this will give us an ability to trace all three abundant early solar system volatiles (CO, CO2 and H2O) in primitive bodies. Our team has accumulated a large set of cometary imaging data over the past 3 decades, and through datasets that include the Spitzer large comet nucleus survey, the NEOWISE small body survey, the new Pan STARRS 1 survey in Hawai’i, we now have sufficient information to model comet heliocentric activity over many apparitions to understand the basic volatile compositions and look for trends that can be tied to orbital properties.

As NEOWISE team members we undertook the core task to gather optical images for all NEOWISE comets observed to have excess emission in the W2 band.  These observations are a crucial component of the NEOWISE mission objective to provide the community with the most extensive uniform data set of production rates, heliocentric light curves, and R-band photometry.  Since the mission restart in 2014, ~200 comets have been observed by NEOWISE, and to date our ground-based CFHT observing program has followed up ~82% of the active comets observed by NEOWISE.  All optical data acquired through this program will be made available to the general community via the Planetary Data System archive.  We conducted rapid follow up for all newly discovered and known comets detected by NEOWISE, and used this data to estimate limits on CO2 and CO gas production.  We have successfully combined ground-based photometry with production rates for CO and H2O obtained with the NIRSPEC instrument on Keck, and CO2 production rates obtained from the NEOWISE survey, along with other published water production rates to make self-consistent sublimation model of the cometary activity (Figure 1 and Figure 2).
